title: Shape Up
text:
Q. What's the first step of shaping?
A. Setting boundaries.
exact: The first step of shaping is setting boundaries on what we’re trying to do.
suffix: The conversations we have are g

selector.exact: The first step of shaping is setting boundaries on what we’re trying to do.
selector.suffix: The conversations we have are g

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. Give an example of a "grab-bag" project definition.
A. e.g. "Redesign the Files section", "Files 2.0"
prefix: a single problem or use case.
exact: When someone proposes something like “redesign the Files section,” that’s a grab-bag, not a project.
suffix: It’s going to be very hard to f

selector.exact: When someone proposes something like “redesign the Files section,” that’s a grab-bag, not a project.
selector.prefix: a single problem or use case.
selector.suffix: It’s going to be very hard to f

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. Give an example of a more viable way to frame a project to "redesign the Files section".
A. e.g. "Make it easier to share multiple files"
prefix: e it starts, and where it ends.
exact: Here’s a more productive starting point: “We need to rethink the Files section because sharing multiple files takes too many steps.”
suffix: Now we can start asking: What’s

selector.exact: Here’s a more productive starting point: “We need to rethink the Files section because sharing multiple files takes too many steps.”
selector.prefix: e it starts, and where it ends.
selector.suffix: Now we can start asking: What’s

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. What's wrong with "redesign" or "refactoring" projects?
A. Their scope and purpose are usually unclear.
prefix: at’s a grab-bag, not a project.
exact: It’s going to be very hard to figure out what it means, where it starts, and where it ends.
suffix: Here’s a more productive starti

selector.exact: It’s going to be very hard to figure out what it means, where it starts, and where it ends.
selector.prefix: at’s a grab-bag, not a project.
selector.suffix: Here’s a more productive starti

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. What to do if your appetite is small and you can't distill a clear use case for a product request?
A. Just work on something else. Maybe future interactions will inspire new ideas.
prefix: ow much research is worthwhile.
exact: If it’s not critical now and we can’t get our hands around the problem, we’ll walk away from it and work on something else.
suffix: Maybe in the future a new reque

selector.exact: If it’s not critical now and we can’t get our hands around the problem, we’ll walk away from it and work on something else.
selector.prefix: ow much research is worthwhile.
selector.suffix: Maybe in the future a new reque

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. What key insight did the Basecamp team discover when they interviewed the user who requested a calendar?
A. Her real need was "find free spaces for appointments" (not "create a complete digital calendar")
prefix: vious. What we learned was that
exact: “see free spaces” was the important thing for this use case, not “do everything a calendar does.”
suffix: This story, and others like it

selector.exact: “see free spaces” was the important thing for this use case, not “do everything a calendar does.”
selector.prefix: vious. What we learned was that
selector.suffix: This story, and others like it

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. To narrow down a user's request for a calendar, what did the Basecamp team ask them?
A. When did she want it? What was she doing then? (Not why she wanted it, or what it should look like…)
prefix: mer who asked for this feature.
exact: Instead of asking her why she wants a calendar and what it should look like, we asked her when she wanted a calendar
suffix: . What was she doing when the th

selector.exact: Instead of asking her why she wants a calendar and what it should look like, we asked her when she wanted a calendar
selector.prefix: mer who asked for this feature.
selector.suffix: . What was she doing when the th

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. When appetite demands that a request be solved in tighter scope, what should you ask about the workflow?
A. Where, specifically, is the current workflow really breaking down?
prefix: dar, how do we narrow it down?
exact: In that case we flip from asking “What could we build?” to “What’s really going wrong?” Sure, a calendar sounds nice. But what is driving the request? At what point specifically does someone’s current workflow break down without this thing they’re asking for?
suffix: Case study: Defining “calendar

selector.exact: In that case we flip from asking “What could we build?” to “What’s really going wrong?” Sure, a calendar sounds nice. But what is driving the request? At what point specifically does someone’s current workflow break down without this thing they’re asking for?
selector.prefix: dar, how do we narrow it down?
selector.suffix: Case study: Defining “calendar

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. In the example of a customer requesting more complex permission rules, what did Basecamp discover was really going on, and how did that affect the solution?
A. Someone had accidentally archived a file; instead of creating a complex permission system, they added a simple warning.
prefix: everyone else using the system.
exact: Instead of creating a rule to prevent some people from archiving, we realized we could put a warning on the archive action itself that explains the impact.
suffix: That’s a one-day change instead

selector.exact: Instead of creating a rule to prevent some people from archiving, we realized we could put a warning on the archive action itself that explains the impact.
selector.prefix: everyone else using the system.
selector.suffix: That’s a one-day change instead

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. What's the default place raw product ideas are stored at Basecamp?
A. Nowhere: they don't use a backlog because they don't want to end up with an ever-growing pile of underspecified work.
prefix: at leaves all our options open.
exact: We don’t put it in a backlog.
suffix: We give it space so we can lear

selector.exact: We don’t put it in a backlog.
selector.prefix: at leaves all our options open.
selector.suffix: We give it space so we can lear

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. What's the default reaction to raw product ideas at Basecamp?
A. A soft "no"—"maybe someday," until someone's inspired to work on the idea enough to bet resources on.
prefix: ding to raw ideas
exact: Our default response to any idea that comes up should be: “Interesting. Maybe some day.” In other words, a very soft “no”
suffix: that leaves all our options ope

selector.exact: Our default response to any idea that comes up should be: “Interesting. Maybe some day.” In other words, a very soft “no”
selector.prefix: ding to raw ideas
selector.suffix: that leaves all our options ope

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. Why is there no absolute definition of "the best" solution?
A. A solution can only be judged in the context of how much time we want to spend on it and how important it is.
prefix: with fewer design constraints.
exact: We can only judge what is a “good” solution in the context of how much time we want to spend and how important it is.
suffix: Responding to raw ideas

selector.exact: We can only judge what is a “good” solution in the context of how much time we want to spend and how important it is.
selector.prefix: with fewer design constraints.
selector.suffix: Responding to raw ideas

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. How does appetite affect how shaped ideas are built?
A. It forces the team to make trade-offs.
prefix: hen we hand the work to a team,
exact: the fixed time box pushes them to make decisions about what is core to the project and what is peripheral or unnecessary
suffix:
.

“Good” is relative

selector.exact: the fixed time box pushes them to make decisions about what is core to the project and what is peripheral or unnecessary
selector.prefix: hen we hand the work to a team,
selector.suffix:
.

“Good” is relative

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. How does appetite affect the shaping process?
A. It constrains the design of solutions.
prefix: to building and shipping them.
exact: First, the appetite constrains what kind of a solution we design during the shaping process.
suffix: Later, when we hand the work to

selector.exact: First, the appetite constrains what kind of a solution we design during the shaping process.
selector.prefix: to building and shipping them.
selector.suffix: Later, when we hand the work to

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. To plan based on appetite, we use this principle: "??? time, ??? scope".
A. fixed, variable
prefix: straint on the design process.
exact: This principle, called “fixed time, variable scope,”
suffix: is key to successfully defining

selector.exact: This principle, called “fixed time, variable scope,”
selector.prefix: straint on the design process.
selector.suffix: is key to successfully defining

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. "Estimates start with a ??? and end with a ???. Appetites start with a ??? and end with a ???."
A. design, number; number, design
prefix: ely different from an estimate.
exact: Estimates start with a design and end with a number. Appetites start with a number and end with a design.
suffix: We use the appetite as a creati

selector.exact: Estimates start with a design and end with a number. Appetites start with a number and end with a design.
selector.prefix: ely different from an estimate.
selector.suffix: We use the appetite as a creati

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. What if a project's scope doesn't fit in a six-week cycle?
A. Hammer it down, or break off a meaningful piece that can fit.
prefix: e-size team a full six-weeks.
exact: In rare cases where the scope is so big that a six-week project isn’t conceivable, we’ll try to hammer it down by narrowing the problem definition. If we still can’t shrink the scope, we’ll break off a meaningful part of the project that we can shape to a six-week appetite.
suffix: Fixed time, variable scope

selector.exact: In rare cases where the scope is so big that a six-week project isn’t conceivable, we’ll try to hammer it down by narrowing the problem definition. If we still can’t shrink the scope, we’ll break off a meaningful part of the project that we can shape to a six-week appetite.
selector.prefix: e-size team a full six-weeks.
selector.suffix: Fixed time, variable scope

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. How are "small batch" projects handled in the six week cycles?
A. Several are combined in a single six-week cycle.
prefix: can build in one or two weeks.
exact: We batch these together into a six week cycle (more on that later).
suffix: Big Batch: This project takes

selector.exact: We batch these together into a six week cycle (more on that later).
selector.prefix: can build in one or two weeks.
selector.suffix: Big Batch: This project takes

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. What standard sizes does Basecamp usually use for appetite?
A. Small batch (takes a team 1-2 weeks); big batch (same team, 6 weeks)
prefix: the appetite in two sizes:
exact:
Small Batch: This is a project that a team of one designer and one or two programmers can build in one or two weeks. We batch these together into a six week cycle (more on that later).
  Big Batch: This project takes the same-size team a full six-weeks.
suffix: In rare cases where the scope

selector.exact:
Small Batch: This is a project that a team of one designer and one or two programmers can build in one or two weeks. We batch these together into a six week cycle (more on that later).
  Big Batch: This project takes the same-size team a full six-weeks.
selector.prefix: the appetite in two sizes:
selector.suffix: In rare cases where the scope

title: Shape Up
text:
Q. What's meant by "appetite"?
A. A time budget (assuming a standard team size)
prefix:
ak?

We call this the appetite.
exact: You can think of the appetite as a time budget for a standard team size.
suffix: We usually set the appetite in

selector.exact: You can think of the appetite as a time budget for a standard team size.
selector.prefix:
ak?

We call this the appetite.
